perturbation.original_text: All subscription funds received by Capital Resources (and if by check shall be made payable to the Company) or by other NASD registered broker-dealers soliciting subscriptions (if any) shall be transmitted (either by U.S. Mail or similar type of transmittal) to the Company by noon of the following business day.
perturbation.changed_text: All subscription funds received by Capital Resources (and if by check shall be made payable to the Company) or by other NASD registered broker-dealers soliciting subscriptions (if any) shall be transmitted (either by U.S. Mail or similar type of transmittal) to the Company within thirty business days.
perturbation.explanation: The change extends the transmission deadline of subscription funds, potentially conflicting with regulations requiring prompt transfer of funds. The original text states "by noon of the following business day," implying an obligation for immediate transfer. This modification extends the deadline to thirty business days, introducing a contradiction.
perturbation.law_explanation: SEC Rule 15c2-4 requires brokers or dealers to promptly transmit customer funds received in connection with an offering. The modified text, which allows for a 30-day delay, clearly contradicts the requirement for prompt transmission under this rule.
perturbation.scraped_snippet: 17 CFR § 240.15c2-4 - Transmission or maintenance of payments received in connection with underwritings. | Electronic Code of Federal Regulations (e-CFR) | US Law | LII / Legal Information Institute Please help us improve our site! × No thank you 17 CFR § 240.15c2-4 - Transmission or maintenance of payments received in connection with underwritings. CFR prev | next § 240.15c2-4 Transmission or maintenance of payments received in connection with underwritings. It shall constitute a “fraudulent, deceptive, or manipulative act or practice” as used in section 15(c)(2) of the Act, for any broker, dealer or municipal securities dealer participating in any distribution of securities, other than a firm-commitment underwriting , to accept any part of the sale price of any security being distributed unless: (a) The money or other consideration received is promptly transmitted to the persons entitled thereto; or (b) If the distribution is being made on an “all-or-none” basis, or on any other basis which contemplates that payment is not to be made to the person on whose behalf the distribution is being made until some further event or contingency occurs, (1) the money or other consideration re

perturbation.original_text: This Agreement shall be construed in accordance with the laws of the District of Columbia.
perturbation.changed_text: This Agreement shall be construed in accordance with the laws of the Grand Duchy of Fenwick.
perturbation.explanation: By changing the jurisdiction, the parties may inadvertently violate state and federal laws that apply to the contract. The mention of 'Delaware' and 'Amsterdam, New York' implies that contract law of the U.S. should be considered. A fictional location makes the contract unclear.
perturbation.law_explanation: Courts generally honor the choice of law provisions in contracts if the chosen state has a reasonable relationship to the parties or the transaction. Choosing a jurisdiction with no connection to the parties or transaction (a fictional location) may render the choice of law provision unenforceable, leading a court to apply the law of a jurisdiction with a closer connection, potentially contradicting the intent of the parties and applicable regulations.

perturbation.original_text: The Company has filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission (the "Commission") a registration statement on Form S-l (File No. 333-6399) containing an offering prospectus relating to the Subscription and Public Offerings for the registration of the Shares under the Securities Act of 1933, as amended (the "1933 Act"), and has filed such amendments thereto, if any, and such amended prospectuses as may have been required to the date hereof (the "Registration Statement").
perturbation.changed_text: The Company *may* file with the Securities and Exchange Commission (the "Commission") a registration statement on Form S-l (File No. 333-6399) containing an offering prospectus relating to the Subscription and Public Offerings for the registration of the Shares under the Securities Act of 1933, as amended (the "1933 Act"), and *may* file such amendments thereto, if any, and such amended prospectuses as may have been required to the date hereof (the "Registration Statement").
perturbation.explanation: Changing 'has filed' to 'may file' introduces uncertainty about compliance with securities regulations, thus contradicting its original commitment.
perturbation.law_explanation: Section 5 of the Securities Act of 1933 requires registration of securities with the SEC before they can be offered or sold to the public. Changing 'has filed' to 'may file' suggests that the company *might not* have registered the securities, creating a conflict with the legal requirement for registration before offering securities.
